Author: cstejerean
Content:
well, a big difference in total LOC might be significant, but that's slightly different claim than saying that a difference in LOC for "hello, world" has any importance.

The reason you can get by with a shorter hello world program in most dynamic languages is because you're doing it in the "module" definition, which I think is not proper form in any non trivial programs. So any differences in LOC for hello world really mean nothing over the course of a real application.

Author: axod
Content: It is a matter of taste and opinion though. We had a programmer at our office who used to use strings for everything. Any datatype, he'd use a string anyway.\nHe thought it made things uniform and easy. So he'd probably feel the urge to rewrite everything. That doesn't mean it's bad code, it just means he has issues :)

Author: pg
Content:
When speakers at YC dinners take questions at the end, there's one I ask most of them: what do you know now that you didn't know when you were 24? The most common answer is to trust your instincts about people. If you're thinking of working with someone but something seems iffy about them, don't.

So you probably did the right thing.

Friends can help you screen people. Especially female friends, who often have a more sensitive social radar than men.

Author: DarrenStuart
Content: and most of the world still uses it so we have to deal with it. At least its not IE 5...

Author: DarrenStuart
Content:
go with your gut I say. Only you know what ticks the boxes for you. Also never look back at what could of been...

I have worked with people that I have disliked but over time I have ended up getting on with them quite well in the end. Sometimes first impressions can be wrong.
